title: Polarization
description: Dividing into two sharply contrasting groups or opinions. A state in which the opinions, beliefs, or interests of a group or society no longer range along a continuum but become concentrated at opposing extremes.
examples: Don’t believe the other party’s lies. They said they care about workers but more people are out of work than ever.
I don’t trust people from the other team. They’re lazy and cheat.
explanation:
It preys on the tendency of people with strong beliefs to dislike and distrust those different from themselves.
Hostile “othering” language can reinforce biases, separating and dividing groups even further.
actions: Be skeptical of arguments that cast blame on a person or group.
Be wary when you see a serious/complex problem reduced to blame on an individual or a single group of individuals.
